title: The decline of the apostrophe
intro: A retired journalist who founded a campaign to preserve the correct use of the apostrophe in the English language, is giving up his battle.  It's because he says "ignorance has won". We discuss what's causing the decline in the use of this punctuation mark and teach you some vocabulary along the way.

Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: Someone overly concerned with correcting small mistakes
to stay in a place longer
to walk around with no real purpose or desire to get somewhere quickly
at risk, possibly not going to happen
a lack of knowledge about something

transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English, I'm Georgina.

transcript.text: And I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Are you a punctuation pedant ? Do you get upset, annoyed or angry if you see punctuation being used incorrectly – particularly apostrophes?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, it depends. Usually I’m pretty chilled out about it, but sometimes, just sometimes it really winds me up. For example, if I see a sign for taxis at a train station and it says taxi – apostrophe - s – aargh! Why – why? The apostrophe is not used to show there is more than one, it’s used to show there is a missing letter or that the word is a possessive – it’s just wrong! So that does kind of make my blood boil.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So, when you say you’re pretty chilled about it you mean…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, I’m not chilled at all. But maybe I wish I were.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Well, we’re going to be taking a look at reactions to the use and abuse of apostrophes in this programme. But first, a question. The word ‘apostrophe’ itself – which language does it come from? Is it:

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I don’t think it’s Arabic, so it’s a toss-up between Latin and Greek. I’m going to say Greek.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: OK. We’ll see if you’re correct at the end of the programme. The apostrophe, it is true to say, is often misused. It’s put where it shouldn’t be and not used where it should be. Is it important, though? Does it matter? After all, in spoken English there is no difference between ‘it’s’ with an apostrophe and ‘its’ without. ‘Your’ and ‘you’re’ – short for ‘you are’ sound the same. So what’s the problem in written English?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: In many cases there isn’t a problem at all. There would be very little confusion. But I don’t think that means we should just ignore the correct way to use them. Sometimes it can be very important to make clear if it’s a singular or plural or possessive. Another important thing to remember is that in CVs and job applications a good standard of spelling and punctuation is expected. Get it wrong and you could miss out on a good opportunity.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: There is one group that has tried for nearly 20 years to keep others to these high standards - The Apostrophe Protection Society. They have publicly pointed out incorrect use in public signs and communications – a tactic that has not always been welcome or successful. But like the apostrophe itself, the group is in danger. Here’s a BBC news report on the subject.

transcript.author: Duncan Kennedy, BBC reporter
transcript.text: They linger above our letters, they wander around the endings of our words, but apostrophes, it seems, are an endangered species. The Apostrophe Protection Society – yes there really is one – says their future is, well, up in the air .

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: How does he describe apostrophes?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Using metaphorical, poetic language, he says they linger above our letters. To linger is a verb usually used to describe someone or something staying somewhere before finally leaving.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So, we have apostrophes lingering above our letters and also he said they wander around the ending of words.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, also a metaphorical use. To wander means to walk slowly around without any real purpose or urgency.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And he went on to say that the future of the apostrophe is up in the air . When something is up in the air , it means its future is not certain, it’s not guaranteed. So if, for example, your holiday plans are up in the air , it means that there is some kind of problem and you might not be going on holiday after all. The person who founded The Apostrophe Protection Society is John Edwards. Now 96 years old he has decided to give it up. Partly because of his age, but also because he thinks that due to the impact of texting and social media he has lost the battle against bad punctuation. So why has it come to this? Here he is explaining why he thinks people aren’t bothered about using correct punctuation.

transcript.author: John Edwards
transcript.text: I think it’s a mixture of ignorance and laziness. They’re too ignorant to know where it goes, they’re too lazy to learn so they just don’t bother. The barbarians have won.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So what’s his reason?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: He blames ignorance and laziness. Ignorance is a lack of knowledge or understanding of something. So people don’t know the rules and are too lazy to learn them, according to Edwards.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Quite strong views there!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, and you thought I was a pedant ! He actually goes further to say that the barbarians have won. Barbarian is a historical word for people who weren’t part of so-called civilized society. They were seen as violent and aggressive, primitive and uncivilized.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So it’s not a compliment then?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh no!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Right, before we review today’s vocabulary, let’s have the answer to today’s quiz. Which language does the word apostrophe come from? What did you say?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I went for Greek.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Congratulations to you and anyone else who got that right. Greek is the right answer. Now let’s remind ourselves of today’s vocabulary. First, what’s a pedant , Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A pedant is someone who corrects other people’s small mistakes – particularly in grammar and punctuation – but it’s not the same as an English teacher! A pedant will correct native speakers’ mistakes too, and not in the classroom.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: To linger means to stay somewhere for longer.

transcript.author: Rob

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: If your plans are up in the air , it means they are at risk and might not happen.

transcript.author: Rob

transcript.author: Georgina
